title: Kenya: Facebook Entry to Disrupt Kenya's Telcom Sector
text:
Kenya: Senate Demands Audit On Cash for the Elderly 
It will continue to focus on tailoring solutions, metrics and ad formats to the needs of customers and advertisers in the mobile-first, mobile-only African environment," said Ari Kesisoglu the regional director, Middle East and Africa at Facebook. 
Telcos have good reason to be afraid as more technology giants plot their big moves against network operators. 
Facebook is joined by Google that has local presence and has launched a mobile network with ultra-fast broadband in the US called Project Fi. 
NEXUS 
In a bid to increase its revenue, Google could diversify its service offering to Africa, the service allows owners of its latest own-brand Nexus handset to pay the web giant for connectivity rather than a more expensive mobile operator. 
Safaricom and Airtel are pushing government to come up with regulations that will ensure 'over the top' service providers are licensed locally and pay taxes to government. The telcos say the providers are riding on their pre-existing infrastructure. 
Safaricom director of corporate affairs Stephen Chege said Safaricom has welcomed the entry of Facebook into the market but there is need for ministry of ICT and Communications Authority of Kenya to give a way forward should the providers directly compete with their services. 
"Regulators should consider regulations for OTT players that cover licensing, spectrum, security and revenues. Should OTT services such as VOIP continue to grow, mobile network operators will be forced to charge their subscribers a premium fee to access the services," said Airtel Kenya director of corporate affairs Dick Omondi.
